Fields.DialogueText: Henley! Taking stock of the food pantry again, I see.
I'm at war, Captain.
We're all at war, Henley.
And my stomach is winning.
Ah, I see. Well, hurry up and whip something up. I can't have you down here all day. I need eyes on deck.
Captain! You can't rush a good meal. Give me some time...or better yet, how fast do you think you can make a tuna sandwich?

Fields.MenuText: Oh, no - I see where this is going. Make your own sandwich, Henley!
A lot faster than you, apparently. Why do you ask?
Are you asking me to make you a sandwich, Henley? If I make you a sandwich, will it motivate you to do the deck duties?

Fields.DialogueText: Calm down, Captain, I never even asked! I was obviously just wondering...
That's no way to talk to a lady! You have no idea what I'm capable of. Never mind, Captain.
Oh, Captain, nothing motivates me like a grilled tuna sandwich! Especially if a kind person makes it for me.
*ALARM*
Looks like you'll have to put lunch on the backburner for now, Henley. Seems like we have some company.
Oh...how am I supposed to fight on an empty stomach!?
Well, the Morganas are the ones keeping you from that delicious tuna sandwich. Doesn't that make you angry?
Ahhh! In the sweet name of tuna, attack!
@BATTLE
Wow, Henley. You're one hell of a fighter, I'll give you that.
Nobody can keep this girl from a well-deserved meal!
Perhaps that last battle does warrant a tuna sandwich.
Oh Captain! Are you saying you'll make me lunch? You certainly do know how to boost morale on board.
Captain, the sandwich you made me earlier was nothing short of amazing! It's like you studied culinary arts for years or something.
Thanks, Henley, but I assure you that there are much greater accomplishments than putting together a tuna sandwich.
I'm not sure about that. A well-made tuna sandwich deserves to be ranked among... I don't know. The invention of the wheel?
You're quite the character, Henley, you know that?
What else would you expect from a William and Mary graduate?

Fields.MenuText: You went to College of William and Mary?
Since when do they have a campus in the middle of the ocean?
Wow, I never realized you were so educated, Henley. You really graduated from the College of William and Mary?

Fields.DialogueText: I really did, Captain! I have a degree and everything!
Captain! I have no reason to lie about that. I did graduate, I swear I did. I'd swear it over every tuna sandwich left in the world!
I really did, Captain. You don't believe me? Do you think I'm some sort of dummy or something?
Look, Henley, don't take it the wrong way. I just find it kind of hard to believe.
Well, it's true, Captain.
And I'll believe it when I see some proof. The proof is in the pudding.
Oooh, pudding! I could go for some dessert, Captain.
Looks like you'll have to hold off on the sweet tooth, Henley. Look starboard.
Oh, you're kidding me! Stupid Morganas just don't know when to quit.
Well, let's hope that great education taught you a thing or two about battle.
Captain, I learned everything I know about battle from my experience in these waters.
Maybe they've got an ocean campus after all.
@BATTLE
Grr... Maybe they do!
Captain... Captain!
What is it, Henley? Can't you see I'm busy here? Is it urgent?
I don't know, Captain. Would you consider the integrity of my educational background important?
Or, I guess, my integrity as it pertains to my educational background.

Fields.MenuText: Uh... what? Henley, what are you talking about?
Well, I guess it's somewhat important. How is it going to help us in battle?
Sure it is! A person should be entitled to their rightful background.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you serious, Captain? What am I talking about? Did you really forget already?
Ah! For a ship captain, you know nothing about confidence and morale.
That's right! ... Wait, are you agreeing with me? Uh... well, either way, it's important, Captain!
Get on with it, then. What's so important that you need to distract me from this paperwork?
This ring, Captain. The only way you can get this ring is by graduating from the College of William and Mary, and I have it.
Okay...
Ah! You're so frustrating, Captain. You're like a cereal box that just won't open!
What?
Remember, Captain? The proof is in the sauce?
Pudding?
Whatever! Look, this ring proves I'm an alum.
How do I know this ring didn't come from some trader you met on the docks?
Are you kidding me? What soulless villain would sell an authentic graduation ring from the College of William and Mary?
Henley, I'm sorry, but if you really want me to believe you, I'm going to need some more substantial evidence.
You're a frustrating person, Captain.
It's time to channel that frustration, Henley. Seems our last group of visitors may have called some friends in.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Damn! Speaking of soulless villains...
Henley! What are you making all this racket for? It sounds like there's an elephant on board.
It's none of your concern, Captain! You probably wouldn't even believe me if I told you.
None of my concern? You're flipping your room upside down. It's an utter mess!
I'm looking for my yearbook, Captain. I can't find it anywhere.

Fields.MenuText: Look, Henley, if you've gone through the trouble of tearing your room apart, I know you couldn't possibly be lying. Now give it a rest!
Henley, an elaborate prank is one thing, but you're taking this whole William and Mary thing to the next level.
I have a couple minutes to spare. I'll help you look for it. But you have to stop throwing stuff around the room, okay?

Fields.DialogueText: You really think that, Captain? Well it's too late. I'm a woman on a mission now, and I'm not going to stop until I find that book!
Are you kidding me, Captain? Why is it so hard to believe that I'm a college graduate?
Oh, Captain, first you make me a sandwich, and now you want to help me look for my lost yearbook? You're sweet, Captain, sweet as pumpkin pie.
Look, Henley, I can't have you tearing this room apart. I'm sorry if I offended you earlier, but we have men trying to sleep on board now...
Hey, look! There it is - my yearbook!
"College of William and Mary..." Well, I'll be damned, Henley. Maybe you were right. I won't believe it until I see your picture in there, though!
*ALARM*
Wait, Captain! My picture's on page... Oh, what page is it again?
No time, Henley. Hear that? That's the alarm, and it means we could be in danger. Remember... because we're at war.
Right! Well, let's sink these mystery jokers, then. And after, I'm going to show you this yearbook photo whether you like it or not!
@BATTLE
Henley, it's strange that you would be so proud of your picture being in that yearbook and not even know what page it's on.
You know what, Captain? I think you owe me another meal if I find this picture.

Fields.MenuText: What? Proving your educational integrity isn't reward enough?
Okay, Henley, you're on. I'll play chef again if you can prove to me that you're in this book.
Perhaps you forget, Henley, that I am the captain of this vessel. I call the orders, not you.

Fields.DialogueText: It would be, but all this work has made me so hungry!
Deal, Captain! You better start boiling the water. It's just a matter of time. I think I'd like spaghetti with meat sauce!
Well, gee, Captain. You sure do know how to take the fun out of things. Sorry I asked.
Aha! Here it is!
Captain! We've spotted some enemy ships heading towards the bow. They're coming in hot.
Sorry, Henley. Seems the Morganas have returned for another taste.
Will you just look at this picture for a second!?
No time, Henley! Prepare yourself for battle. That's an order!
@BATTLE
So what do you think, Captain? Still don't believe me?
Well, that certainly is your picture...
Mmhmm...
Yes, I can tell by the mustard stain on your shirt.
What? Aw, damn! I never noticed that before.
Although, truth be told, I'm having a hard time looking at your picture with those thick black scribbles underneath it.
Oh, that? That's nothing, Captain. Hear that? That's my tummy grumbling, and I do believe you owe me spaghetti!
Not so fast, Henley. Did someone write an inscription underneath your picture? Why did you scribble it out?
Captain! I told you it was nothing. Now mind your own business!

Fields.MenuText: Wait a minute! You invited me to this business, and now you're trying to leave out the details?
Oh, no, something tells me that there's a juicy story behind that thick layer of ink.
Fine then, Henley. You don't want to tell me? Then no spaghetti for you!

Fields.DialogueText: It's nothing! Don't be so nosy!
Perhaps there is a juicy story, but you're never going to hear about it, so you might as well give up now, Captain!
What!? Captain... you can't. How am I supposed to fight on an empty stomach?
Look, Captain, it was just... something written by an old friend of mine. Case closed. Let's go to the kitchen.
Please, Henley. I may have been at sea for a while, but I wasn't born yesterday. You wouldn't do that to something an old friend wrote. Come on...
I'm starting to get angry and hungry at the same time, Captain.
Why did you cross out the inscription? Was it from a college enemy of yours? Did some scholarly vixen steal your school sweetheart?
Captain, you really have no idea what you're talking about sometimes, don't you?
Captain! Sorry to interrupt, but we have a fleet of Morganas flanking portside.
Looks like that juicy story will have to wait.
You owe me spaghetti, Captain!
Can it, Henley. No one's going to get any spaghetti if we don't survive this battle. Now get ready to fight.
@BATTLE
Henley... are you okay?
Does it look like I'm okay, Captain?
Well, no. That's why I asked.
I'm not okay, Captain. I'm starving!
Well, go make yourself some lunch, Henley. I half expected you to have eaten all the food rations already. Luckily, we're still packed to the gills.
What are you saying, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Do Belles have to worry about gaining weight? Because, considering the amount you eat...
Look, I'm not trying to imply anything, Henley. Other than the obvious fact that you've got a big appetite.
I'm trying to say get off your lazy bum, quit complaining, and whip yourself up some food!

Fields.DialogueText: Captain! You may know how to sail a ship, but you have no idea how to treat a lady. You're downright mean.
I suppose you're right, Captain. Battles just make me so hungry! I don't even know where it all goes.
Lazy bum? How dare you, Captain! You were the one who promised to make me lunch.
All I'm saying is, instead of rolling around on the deck, clutching your stomach and complaining, you ought to go downstairs and make yourself some food.
Thanks, Captain, but I'm on a hunger strike.
Words I never expected to come out of your mouth...
Boy, I lucked out with your sense of humor.
We had a deal, Captain, and I'm not going to eat anything unless it's the spaghetti you promised to make!
Ah, now I see. Well, how about this? You tell me what's really going on with that inscription you scribbled out, and then I'll make you lunch. Sound good?
No, that does not sound good! You changed the deal, Captain! That's unfair.
There's no fairness in war. Now what do you say?
I say turn around and look off the stern, Captain.
Damn... Morganas! Looks like we'll have to save negotiations for another time, Henley. Make sure the torpedoes are ready for fire. We fight!
@BATTLE
Your battle skills never disappoint, Henley. You're an ace in the hole, that's for sure.
Whatever, Captain. Quit trying to act nice.
Oh, come on now, Henley. Don't be sour. You know the terms and conditions if you want me to make you lunch.
Why are you toying with me like this?

Fields.MenuText: Henley, Henley, Henley... We have a lot of time, and we're in the middle of the ocean. What else am I supposed to do? It's fun!
Listen, Henley, I'm a sailor who keeps my word, but I also know how to bargain. You wanted to tell me about your college days, and I feel I'm entitled to the whole story.
Henley, I have a lot of responsibilities on this ship. Making lunch might seem like a simple task, but it takes a lot of time out of my day.

Fields.DialogueText: My embarrassment and starvation is your entertainment? You truly are a warmonger, Captain!
Oh, Captain. Entitled? Entitled to my past? Ah! Last time I ever share something with you.
And you use my past as leverage, Captain? This war truly has warped you.
All right, fine! I'll tell you about the stupid lady whose inscription I crossed out in the yearbook, but you have to promise me something.
War is a terrible time to make promises, Henley. I'd prefer not to...
You make me lunch, and that's it. No more changing the conditions! I tell you about the inscription, and you make me lunch, and that's that!
All right, Henley, I guess that is a pretty good trade. You've got yourself a deal.
And I want homemade meat sauce. Nothing from a can!
And now the demands start going up...
*BOOM*
Morganas! Prepare yourself, Henley.
Oh... I'm never going to get to eat.
@BATTLE
All right, Captain. Fine, I'll fess up. The person who wrote the inscription, her name was... Ralph Talbot.
Her name was... Ralph? This is not the way I was expecting the story to go.
Oh, quiet, you. The more you talk, the longer it will take me to get through this story.
All right, all right.
Ralph Talbot is my sister, another Bagley-class destroyer with the US Navy. We used to be so close...
Yeah, yeah, yeah... get to the part where you guys fight and scratch each other's eyes out.
Ah! You're so impatient, Captain.
Says the girl who is too impatient to make her own lunch.
As I was saying... we were both so close. But when it came time to choose our colleges...

Fields.MenuText: What happened? Did she try to sabotage your admission?
I can't believe I'm listening to a story of two ships choosing their colleges.
This is where things get juicy, right?

Fields.DialogueText: No, no, nothing like that.
I'm sure you've heard stranger things since the war started.
Try not to sound quite so excited, Captain.
It's nothing so dramatic. Just... I chose the College of William and Mary, and she chose Yale. And... nothing was really ever the same, after that.
How so?
*ALARM*
But it looks like I'll have to wait to hear the whole story.
@BATTLE
I think that's the last of them. Looks like we can finally breathe again.
Breathe, and eat!
Henley, I'm not sure you ever stop thinking about food.
Certainly not when you owe me lunch!
Well, hold on now, you haven't told me the whole story yet...
Oh, you're never going to feed me!
Okay, fine, no more playing around! I'm going to tell the story, and I'm going to tell it quick so you can hurry up and get your butt cooking in that kitchen!
Okay, no one's stopping you.
Where was I... Oh, that's right. Talbot chose Yale.
There's nothing inherently wrong with that, Henley. Everyone on the planet knows that William and Mary and Yale are both excellent schools.
I know... I was a little disappointed that Talbot had chosen differently, but that... that wasn't the reason for what you saw in the yearbook.
Oh, really?
After Talbot chose Yale, she... she changed.
How so?
Ah, it's difficult to describe. I suppose we both probably changed - college tends to do that to people.
All right...
But I don't think Talbot changed for the better.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds... ominous.
How so?
Finally, some drama!

Fields.DialogueText: Ominous might not be the word I would use...
If you'll stop interrupting me, I'll tell you.
Your glee over this rift between me and my sister is a little off-putting, Captain.
Sorry, sorry.
Talbot, she...
Come on, spit it out. You've got me on the edge of my seat here!
Look out the window. Your attention is needed elsewhere.
Damn, would you look at that fleet. Sound the alarm, Henley. Looks like we have one hell of a fight on our hands!
@BATTLE
Captain... Captain!
Not now, Henley... The radio has just gone on the fritz and no one seems to know a damn thing about fixing it.
Fixing the radio? No, you need to fix me a meal! So fix the radio, do whatever you need to do. But you're going to hear the rest of this story, and you're going to cook for me!

Fields.MenuText: Do you really think your appetite takes precedent over ship operations?
You calling the shots around here now, Henley? Look, as much as I would like to continue our deal, we have a serious issue to deal with.
Henley, you're a bit bossy, but you know what you want and you know how to get it. I like that about you. My ears are open.

Fields.DialogueText: Your word is as valuable as a soggy sandwich, Captain! My appetite has more of an effect than you think. I can't max out my speed if I haven't eaten...
The only shot I'm calling for is insulin, because my blood sugar is dropping at a rapid rate. That's a serious issue, Captain. This is starvation!
Your words are sweet, Captain, but they're not as sweet as the taste of a creamy alfredo sauce. Now listen, before I start trying to eat the radio.
All right, all right. You've got my attention, Henley. What happened? How did you sister change?
The next time she and I met...
Yes?
I hardly recognized her.
Your own sister? You hardly recognized your own sister?
I mean, physically, yes. It was her. There was no doubt about that. But her attitude, the things she said and did...
You still aren't giving me any concrete information here, Henley.
She was harsher. She looked down on everyone and everything around her. Nothing was good enough.
I could see why that would be difficult to deal with.
But that wasn't even the worst of it!
How so?
Captain! We've spotted a fleet of enemy ships portside. What's your command?
Good eyes, scout. Let's put these Morganas on the ocean floor.
@BATTLE
Good work, Henley. You never seem to hold back.
And neither does my appetite, Captain. Do you think we could head to the kitchen? Maybe you could start cooking lunch while I finish telling you my story...
I've finally managed to get you into the galley, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I guess your incessant badgering finally paid off. Don't push your luck.
Looks like it, Henley. You're a hell of a tactician.
Don't get used to it, Henley… you've really earned it this time.

Fields.DialogueText: If I wasn't busy wasting away to bones, then maybe I would express the anger I feel when you open your mouth!
Thanks, Captain… it takes serious patience.
Ah, but Captain… it's so nice when you cook for me.
Whatever you say. Can you hand me the colander?
Colander?
Yeah, the colander?
Right… uh…
The bowl with holes in it!
Oh, duh… of course!
Henley… I figured someone who likes to eat as much as you would know what a colander is.
What a silly mistake. Let's get back to my past. Remember?
Right. Your sister named Ralph.
Be nice, would you? It's not as if any of us can choose our names.
I… I guess you're right on that count.
*ALARM*
Morganas… save it, Henley. We have work to do.
@BATTLE
Ah! The noodles haven't even had a chance to boil yet... sweet William and Mary, is there even a God?
Calm down, Henley. We've been dodging death on these seas for quite some time and you're worried about boiled noodles?
We've been dodging real death, which means we're alive. Which means we still need to eat.

Fields.MenuText: You're hilarious, Henley.
You're a nutcase, Henley.
Hm... I guess I can relate.

Fields.DialogueText: Since when is starvation funny, Captain?
A nutcase? You're the nutcase, Captain. Torturing people with famine...
Aw, I'm glad you agree, Captain. So, since we see things eye to eye... on the double, spaghetti Bolognese!
Look, I think you need to calm down. Tell me the rest of your story.
Fine, fine. Well... when I said Talbot looked down on everyone and everything... that included me.
You? She... what? Made fun of you? For what?
The list of things she never made fun of would take much less time to relay.
Are you serious?
I am. She made fun of my ship. Since I was two months older than she, that somehow made me some sort of relic.
She made fun of my clumsiness. Every time I made even the tiniest mistake, I could be sure she would announce it to the entire world.
I could certainly see how that would get old after a while.
You're not kidding.
*BOOM*
Damn! It's like these Morganas take pleasure in interrupting your story. Hold that thought, Henley. You know what to do.
@BATTLE
You're a hell of a fighter, Henley.
And an even better eater. If only I had something to eat...
Is the radio still down, Captain?
Can't get anything out of it, Henley. We'll just have to wait until the electricians can make sense of it.
Well, if we have to wait half as long as it's taken me to get my food, then you might as well accept a cease of all communications!

Fields.MenuText: Fine, Henley. Back to the galley we go, if only to stop your non-stop complaining.
I have a couple minutes to spare. Let's go fix you up some food!
Look, I know I said I would fix you a meal, but I need to be here until the radio is working again.

Fields.DialogueText: Tease me all you want. You're still making me some food, Captain!
You've never spoken sweeter words, Captain. Lead the way!
Hm... Well, let me ask you, Captain: would you consider a mutiny a higher priority than a working radio?
Okay, I'll finish the meal. But just finish this story, right here, right now. No more waiting around. What happened?
Receiving my degree from the College of William and Mary was one of my proudest moments. And that yearbook... I loved it. All my sisters knew it.
Okay...
The last time I saw Talbot, I found my yearbook a little while after. And she had written the most hateful things underneath my picture.
How William and Mary only gave me the degree because they felt sorry for me, how that would have never happened at Yale...
You're kidding...
Captain!
Tell me the radio is fixed. Please tell me the radio is fixed.
Negative, Captain! I'm sorry to be the bearer of bad news, but we have a fleet of Morgana ships off the bow within range.
There's seldom good news during war. Prepare to fire. Henley... we'll continue this conversation later.
@BATTLE
Listen, Henley, your sister is the worst. That's all there is to it.
I don't blame you for scribbling out what she wrote. If it had been me, I would have tracked down her own yearbook and burned it.
I won't say the thought didn't cross my mind...
But listen, all of those things are in the past now, anyway. You're far away from your sister, and one of the best fighters I've met.
Thanks, Captain.
Whoah, hey! Looks like a little slip of paper just fell out of your book.
What? No! That's nothing...

Fields.MenuText: Nothing, huh?
You expect me to believe that? Come on, what is it really?
Hand it over, Henley. Let's see what other fun facts are hiding in your history.

Fields.DialogueText: I said nothing, Captain! All right, just leave it alone.
Captain... Come on, haven't you done enough digging?
It's mine, Captain! You can be a real jerk sometimes, you know that?
Oh, you dropped it again!
The wind took it! Grab it quick.
Bagley-class... family reunion?
Captain! Give that back!
Ah, come on, this is too good.
Whatever, Captain.
Hey... I'm just messing around. Are you okay?
*ALARM*
Forget the note for a minute, Henley. Seems death is knocking at our door once again.
@BATTLE
Uh... Henley, look. I'm no expert in consoling people on their feelings, but...
It's nothing, Captain. I'm fine. Just leave me alone.
Look, you've been staring at that stupid family reunion invite paper for way too long now. Is there something else? Did something happen at the event?
No... I didn't even go.

Fields.MenuText: Ah, I think I understand now.
The past is in the past, right?
Ha! What? You're crying about something you didn't even go to?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sorry, Captain. I usually don't get all emotional like this, but I'm so hungry... and just seeing Talbot's stupid inscription in the yearbook... Oh, I'm a mess.
I wish I could say that. Aw, this whole thing is making me want some comfort food.
How much ruder could you be?
Listen, family reunions are always terrible. I'm sure you didn't miss anything.
A couple of my other sisters couldn't make it, so I didn't feel too bad... but Bagley put a lot of work into organizing it.
Your sisters really do have some odd names, you know that? You got pretty lucky.
Do you know the thing that made me the most upset?
Nope, this is all new to me. Looks like we'll have to save it for now. You see what I see? Morgana scum. Let's eat them alive.
I might have to at this point!
@BATTLE
Henley, are you okay?
Let it all out, Henley. I can't have you all teary-eyed when Morgana ships skirt through here.
Do you know what made me the maddest? Talbot would always talk about all the things she could do that I couldn't.
There are words for women who act like that...
And all I could think was how she could do so many things I couldn't. Read Latin, cook...
Whoa, Henley? Did you just say you can't learn how to cook?
I know how to make oatmeal! But that's it... I just never had time to learn!
But you love to eat. All you talk about is food.
I guess it does seem kind of strange.

Fields.MenuText: To be honest, Henley, not knowing how to cook makes you sound kind of lazy.
I think now I understand why you're so hungry. Sorry, Henley. I can't help but laugh, though.
Well, that's all right! There's plenty of people in the world who love music but can't play a lick of it.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain you've spent plenty of time on this vessel with me. We're alive, and doing all right. You should know I'm far from lazy.
You can be cruel from time to time, Captain.
I've never heard it put that way, Captain! You're a wordsmith. Your cheery attitude always puts me in a good mood.
Well, Henley, you sitting around the deck crying about sibling dramatics isn't going to do us any good. Seems we have our work cut out for us.
What do you mean, Captain? Maybe we should finish the pasta first, and then we'll come right back to this conversation...
That's exactly what I mean. Henley, it's obvious that there's a... how can I put this delicately... emotional wound from this experience.
I don't know if I'd go that far.
One that's never healed, but I've worked out the cure.
Pasta al dente?
Damn! Looks another fleet of Morgana ships has found us already.
Hey, wait! What's this cure you're talking about?
@BATTLE
Haha! Looks like we live to fight another day... Oh, hell, she's still crying.
*ALARM*
Henley! Just the girl I'm looking for.
Captain? I'm done hoping you'll bring me the food you promised you'd make me.
Don't worry, Henley. Food is on the horizon. Remember when we spoke about your predicament?
Huh?
Your familial hang-ups, Henley. Remember I said I had found the cure? When I told you we had a new objective?
Maybe, Captain, but you're starting to sound crazy.

Fields.MenuText: I act only for the safety and well-being of my beloved crew.
What ship captain isn't at least a little daft? War is crazy, Henley.
I think you mean to say "Starting to sound like a genius."

Fields.DialogueText: You might be overdoing it a little, Captain.
Perhaps you're right, Captain. Is that why you are starving me? Because you're crazy?
Maybe! I guess I'll just have to hear your big plan. You're so confident!
Okay, here it is.
Wait... I don't know if I'm going to like this.
You're going to love it - there's food at the end of the plan.
If that's the case, lay it on me, Captain!
Our mission, Henley, is going to be to make you into a chef. I'm going to teach you how to cook!
*ALARM*
Looks like our first lesson is going to have to be delayed. The only thing we're cooking is Morgana.
Heh! ... I can't believe I actually laughed at that.
@BATTLE
Good work, Captain. You could have played for William and Mary's football team.
Thanks, Henley. But you need to make your way down to the kitchen. That's an order. We have work to do!
You got it, Captain!
Welcome to chef boot camp, Cadet Henley. What's the first thing you should do when starting to prepare a meal?
Hmmm... Sample the ingredients!
This may be harder than I thought. Wrong! Sorry, Henley. The first thing you do is wash your hands.
Right, of course. What's the second thing?
All right, next we're going to make sure we have all of our equipment, ingredients, and a copy of the recipe close by.
Right, where's the copy of the recipe?
Actually I have the recipe...in my head. Guess you'll have to watch me closely.
I'm starting to feel like I'm back in the classes of William and Mary again. Do you really think I can become a chef?

Fields.MenuText: You're a determined and spirited girl... albeit a bit clumsy. But I'm sure you're capable of making spaghetti.
From what I've seen, the chances are slim. But I'll try my best.
Not really, but I think watching you try will be incredibly entertaining.

Fields.DialogueText: Thanks, Captain. You're a hell of a motivator!
Gee, thanks for the vote of confidence, Captain.
Ah! Sometimes I wish you were the captain of a different ship.
All right, have you gathered everything we need?
Pasta noodles, cutting board, tomatoes, beef...
All right, now flip the stove on and boil a pot of water.
Okay, you got it! Water on the stove.
Captain!
Any news on the radio situation? Is it fixed yet?
Still just making fuzz sounds, Captain.  Listen, we've spotted a hostile Morgana fleet just starboard of here.
*BOOM*
Seems they're right on top of us. Sound the alarm.
Wait! Should I turn the stove off?
@BATTLE
You really gave me a fright, Henley. You could have burned yourself to the waterline!
I'm learning, Captain.
I suppose you're right. Boot camp continues then!
*ALARM*
All right, see this block of cheese? We're going to grate it.
Grade it? Tastes like an A+ cut of cheese to me, Captain.
No, Henley... grate it. Grab that metal thing with all the holes in it.
Oh! This, right?
Yeah. Now, slowly slide the block of cheese along the grater like this.
Hey, this is easy! Mmm... I'm getting hungry just looking at all this good food.
Henley! No, don't hold it like that, you're going to shred your finger into a parmesan pile.
Oh! Got it. Thanks, Professor.

Fields.MenuText: I'm your captain, not your professor.
Professor... That has a nice ring to it. You got it, Henley!
Professor? You're making me feel old, Henley.

Fields.DialogueText: Right! Sorry, Captain.
You're a person of many talents, that's for sure.
Oh stop it, Captain. You know I had no such intention.
All right, things are coming along nicely.
Yeah, I'm starting to feel more comfortable in this room.
Henley, you and I both know you've always been comfortable in the kitchen.
*ALARM*
That's one of the disadvantages to taking a cooking class on a naval ship during war. You're always going to be interrupted by battle.
These Morganas are nothing. Let's show them what a couple of chefs are capable of! I could sink them on an empty stomach.
Imagine what you'll do on a full one!
@BATTLE
All right, Henley, we're nearly there.
Good, because I don't think I can stare at this pile of cheese any longer.
Soon enough, Henley. Cooking will teach you to be patient, a necessary characteristic for surviving these waters. There are so many things to learn.
And I appreciate it, Captain, but I'm a little worried. Should I be writing this down? How am I going to remember to do all of these things?

Fields.MenuText: Henley, it's nothing, I promise. With a bit more practice, cooking is just going to come naturally.
You're not taking notes? Well, you probably won't remember.
Henley, it may take some time, but you'll get the gist of the things, I promise you.

Fields.DialogueText: You really think so? Wow... I'm going to be able to make any kind of food whenever I want!
You certainly know how to motivate your students.
Thanks, Coach! Professor. Captain. You can do it all!
All right, next you need to chop up this onion. Think you can handle it?
You'll have to show me which way to slice it, Captain.
All right, all you want to do is cut right down the middle here.
Oh, okay...
Henley, are you okay? I just barely cut into the onion and it looks like there's a flood coming down your cheek. What's wrong?
Captain! Morgana ships approaching the bow.
Oh, they've caught me in a terrible mood. They'll regret it!
@BATTLE
S-sorry, Captain. I just... didn't expect th-the onion to be so... depressing?
What are you still hung up over, Henley? Sounds to me like you just picked the wrong friend.
Captain, I...
There's no use crying over the past when we're fighting for the future.
Look, I just... I really appreciate the help you've been, but they don't just erase the things Talbot said. I'm just a little... overwhelmed.

Fields.MenuText: That's understandable. I'm sorry, Henley.
It's a tough world, Henley, and I guarantee you there are meaner people than your sister out there. You need to develop thicker skin.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, it isn't your fault, Captain.
I suppose you're right, Captain. You may just be right.
Try slicing the onion some more. Cooking can be therapeutic. Plus, I can't have an emaciated crew. You need to eat!
You're funny, Captain. Thanks for trying to cheer me up.
Is the water boiling now?
It's going, Captain!
Throw the noodles in!
Captain! We're getting a transmission through the radio.
It's back up and running! It's a damn miracle.
Command is trying to get a message through. It's fuzzy, but we think we can make it out.
*BOOM*
Looks like Command is just going to have to wait! Morgana ships at the bow!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Look at this war as a chance to prove her wrong about everything.

Fields.DialogueText: Big incentive, Captain! We'll land you a spouse yet.
Henley, I have to get to the radio room and get through to Command. You're going to have to man the galley alone.
Okay... I feel like I'm being tested or something. Ooh! I'm nervous.
You're going to be fine, Henley. Okay?
So all I need to do is stir the noodles and put the sauce in the frying pan. Is that right?
That's it, Henley. See, I knew you would get the hang of this!
Thanks, Captain. I am feeling a little bit better. I can't believe this meal is actually going to happen.
Yep, all thanks to you, Henley. Now, I have to run - don't burn the kitchen down.
Aye-aye, Captain!
Now I just- gah!
Oh no...! Was that the only jar of marinara sauce left?
Henley, what was- oh. The only one...
Oh, we're ruined!

Fields.MenuText: Yep, and I can't help you this time. Get this cleaned up. I have to get to my radio call.
It's no big deal, Henley. No use crying over spilled marinara. We'll think of something.
This does complicate our situation a great deal. Oh, Henley...

Fields.DialogueText: Captain... Oh, I feel like such a failure. I'm sorry, Captain.
Thanks, Captain. You always know the right words to say.
Maybe we should just abort the whole mission. It's silly to think you can just learn to cook at the drop of a dime.
Look. You're going to have to be alert and at your best, Henley. I have an idea.
Captain?
Get this floor cleaned up and wash your hands. Then start slicing tomatoes. You're going to make the sauce by hand.
You really think I'll be able to do that, Captain?
It's our only choice, Henley. Here... I've scribbled down the instructions for you. The spices are in the cabinet.
Captain, thank you.
Save it - I need to go. You're going to make one hell of a sauce.
Oh, thanks, Captain. I'm awfully excited.
Either way it turns out.
What?
*ALARM*
Oh, for... Stir those noodles, Henley, and then move it to the deck! Seems these Morganas want another taste.
@BATTLE
Captain! Look, my sauce. It's... it's delicious. It's stunning... Captain, is everything okay?
The radio call, Henley. There's a highly destructive fleet of Morgana ships that have been spotted just west of here. Command says they're headed right at us.
Captain, that is not good news, but just take a moment to smell the air!

Fields.MenuText: It does smell delicious in here - it could be a kitchen in Florence or Milan. A good one, at that.
Henley, how can you still be so focused on food at a time like this?
Henley, I'm really impressed, honestly. But we have bigger things on our plate right now.

Fields.DialogueText: You really think so, Captain? I owe it all to you!
I just thought maybe you would be proud of my work, Captain. We won't win on an empty stomach.
Captain, you always say that, and we always survive. I say we charge in there, after we eat of course, and fire a torpedo straight at them!
Henley, the noodles!
Oh, right! Ha, I can be so forgetful sometimes. Looks like they're just about done. Now I just throw them in the strainer and let them sit right?
Wow, Henley. You're a quick learner.
Thanks, Captain. I really am feeling better, and I've been doing some thinking.
Sorry, but I need to get back to the deck.
Would you just... I want to show you something. I won't be needing this anymore!
Your family reunion invitation? Hey, wait, you sure you want to rip that up?
Well, it's too late now!
You're looking extra spirited these days, Henley, and I like it!
Thanks, Captain. Now, where are those Morganas?
Scouts spotted ships starboard. Get in position, Henley! Something tells me this battle is just the appetizer before the big main course.
@BATTLE
Those last Morganas were definitely scouts all right. Looks like Command was right.
You think another fleet is headed this way?
I'm certain of it, Henley. Listen, we can't let that beautiful pasta go to waste. You need to mix the sauce and the noodles.
Okay, Captain, you got it.
Now throw the grated cheese on top.
Oh, Captain, this looks and smells so good! Ah, it's getting me so excited. Um... Captain?
Yes?
There's been something I've been meaning to tell you.
Well, considering the fleet of enemy ships headed our way, I think now is the time to ask.
Well, Captain... Sailing with you, and learning how to cook under your leadership... it's been a real pleasure. I'm so pleased you're my Captain.

Fields.MenuText: And I'm pleased to be your Captain. We make a great team.
You're really special, Henley. I wouldn't trade you for anyone else.

Fields.DialogueText: We do, don't we?
I'm so happy to hear you say that, Captain.
Look to the port. The Morganas come already.
@BATTLE
